displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico-

Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me -- Doctor: And that’s the key. Patient: Let me ask you this. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. I have an ache in my hands. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: Um. When I try to – if I try to go to the bathroom without takin’ a laxative –

Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I had to figure out what was gonna on with your lungs. Healthcare Professional: Hi. Doctor: I have a student in here um because I think we gotta work up why your lungs have these areas that don’t seem right. That seems to be your, your thing, every time I see you we’ve got the prostate, oh no we’ve got a lymph node. You know that kind of thing. Um I’m still gonna send you back to the radiation doctor because he may still want to do radiation. You know you’re already on the shot and the next one is in March. But we gotta figure out what’s going on with your lungs. It’s showing some new things in there that may or may not be something that’s cancer. It may not be cancer. I have no idea. Patient: They says it’s nodules or something. Doctor: Exactly. You know nodules are literally white little spots in your lungs. Who knows what that is? It could be a thousand things. Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions?

Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: They’re gonna review the schedule and then tell you when they’re available. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Nice to see you. Stay out of trouble will ya? Patient: I’ll try to. Patient: The best I can. The best I can. Doctor: Oh the best you can. I gotcha. Thanks again for waiting.

Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Today, you know, I mean -- I didn’t know what I have or what I don’t have. I’ve got no pain. I don’t have you know, what did we talk about before? So, then, it’s not a twenty year old’s dream anymore but, um, I would, I would say I probably have waken up a little bit more often which, my sleep patterns really disturbed even from my normal pattern. In that, um, I’m up at two o’clock in the morning and go to the bathroom and then go to sleep until anywhere from (between six and eight.) Doctor: Uh, so you get up and you just can’t get back to sleep? Or, you got something on your mind? Patient: Um. hhh It is, it is mostly just a little bit of, just the wheels won’t stop. Doctor: So, cancer stuff or work stuff? Or at home? Patient: D, all the above. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we were talkin’ about, we were talkin’ about trials? And only some of the trials are medical. So. Doctor: And so, if you don’t get back to sleep in the morning, uh, you fall asleep during the day or? Patient: I’ll take a nap. Maybe an hour’s worth. And then, drive on for the day. From, about three or, three or four - Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Is really the low end. Doctor: And, do you think you’re depressed or?

Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or – Patient: Well, doc, you know -- Doctor: Incontinence or whatever. Patient: Okay. So, no, no. Here, here’s the deal. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Here’s the deal. Okay? (Pause5sec) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: You follow what I’m sayin’, you know? And I know, you know, time might not be that long. You follow what I’m sayin’? You know?

Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We think it’s probably a little bit better tolerated because we’re only giving one drug Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: than it is you know the hair loss, the nausea, the vomiting, Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: you know the numbness of the fingertips, excess tearing, you know changes in blood counts, that you’re at risk for infection, can cause liver injury, nausea, things that you feel

Family Member: I know. I tolerate this guy all by myself. Doctor: I know. All by yourself. Patient: Come on in and have a seat there. I’ve got friends waiting. Doctor: How come I’m over here? Patient: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter) Patient: No. Doctor: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Is that on purpose for filming? Family Member: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink. Family Member: Oh.

Family Member: Does that lead you to believe there’s more there still if it’s higher? Doctor: Yeah then one would think it’s in another part of your body like in the bones or something like that. Family Member: Um hum, um hum. That’s what I worry about too. Doctor: Um the question arose about getting scans on you? Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm,hmm. Doctor: So we (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: If the PSA is anything significant Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Then maybe we would get scans just to have that knowledge. A CT scan and bone scan. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have to sort it out by tomorrow because it’s you know technically Monday’s not a holiday but most people are taking off. Patient: Well I’m thinking it’s Tuesday. Doctor: Yeah that’s why I’m saying it’s got to be a week because you’ve got to fourth and the third is mostly a lot of people are off. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that leaves basically Friday and Wednesday. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?
DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. Doctor: So use that and then date it. That’s right. Family Member: If he does the chemo or radium Doctor: Yeah

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: One of the things we have been interested in is how do we make this drug work better and longer. Okay. And one way to make this drug better, work better and longer is to try to combine it with a second drug that’s experimental. Okay. So the Xtandi itself is not experimental, this has been approved by the FDA more than five years ago. It’s standard, does not require you to participate in a clinical trial and I could just write you a prescription for this medication. The experimental clinical trial that we’re doing which is research, so you would have to sign a permission slip which we call a consent form. Not today but after we’ve had time to look at it. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um and I’ll just flip the page to the back. Okay. It’s a randomized trial. What does randomized mean? Randomized means that at the beginning of the study we flip a coin. Might sound crazy. Doctor: So, I’m going to write randomized. And that coin flip is random. In other words, neither the doctor nor the patient can influence it. We can’t rig the system. Once the coin has been flipped, we can’t flip it again. We can’t keep flipping it until we get the one that we want. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay.

Patient: What about the finasteride I'm still on? Doctor: That's okay. Because you've been taking that for your pee and you’re just being- Patient: I don’t know what’s the other one. Family Member: So okay. Patient: Finasteride and folic acid, we're the only other ones I was taking. Family Member: There's no reason why you can't you take calcium with vitamin nuts. Doctor: No, that's fine. Family Member: Is there anything that's totally good? No, no? As far as meds? Doctor: Well, I don't like Selenium and I don't like vitamin E for prostate cancer patients that's greater than the recommended. Family Member: Selenium? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I take a multivitamin.

Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them?
